awd_titl_txt: RTG: Algebra, Algebraic Geometry, and Number Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a research training group at the University of Georgia in the areas of Algebra, Algebraic Geometry, and Number Theory. Many aspects of the program that have been planned by the University of Georgia Algebra and Number Theory research group will be suitable for and open to all undergraduate and graduate students in the department. Thus these activities will have a broad impact on the life of the department. The training  proposed will run year-round. Keeping the undergraduate, graduate students, and postdocs engaged continuously will help with retention, shorten the time to degree, and boost productivity.

The Algebra, Algebraic Geometry, and Number Theory group at the University of Georgia proposes a comprehensive program designed to recruit, engage, and train students and postdoctoral associates, and to prepare them for successful careers in the mathematical sciences. The First Year Undergraduate Seminars will draw UGA students into careers in the mathematical sciences. The Graduate Student Boot Camp will ensure success for graduate students in the program.  Vertical Research Training Groups (VRTG) will give students and postdocs the chance to engage early in collaborative research projects. The computational VRTG will provide online tools for computations in the three research fields. The Oberseminar will act as educational training tool for graduate students, catalyst for intra-area discussion, and community builder for the group.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RES TRAINING GROUPS IN THE MATH SCIENCES

por.por_cntn:
The RTG grant was focused on the training of junior researchers in Algebraic Geometry, Algebra, and Number Theory (AGANT) at the University of Georgia. The AGANT faculty consists of about seventeen internationally recognized tenure-track and tenured faculty and six postdoctoral fellows.  The RTG was administered by five senior faculty (PI Dino Lorenzini and co-PIs Valery Alexeev, Pete Clark, Angela Gibney, and Daniel Krashen) with the help of many others.

During the tenure of the RTG grant, 31 graduate students in the RTG obtained their Ph.D. degrees. Most found employment immediately after graduation. Five chose to work in industry or government.

The graduate students in the RTG published 27 single-authored research articles and submitted another 9 single-authored preprints for publication.  They were also co-authors on an additional 25 published papers, and submitted 6 preprints with co-authors.  The postdoctoral fellows in the RTG co-authored 11 published articles with other members of the RTG. The undergraduates participating in the RTG were co-authors on 3 published or submitted research articles.

The grant provided funds for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to travel to conferences and network with peers and more senior colleagues. Summer grant funding for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows provided them with adequate research time during the summer.  The grant also offered many professional training opportunities, including about applying for grants and jobs.  For most of our junior members, teaching will be an integral part of their professional life, and we also provided extensive teaching training. All of our junior members were personally mentored by two experienced faculty, their teaching mentor and their research mentor.

The grant provided funding to organize a Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU), as well as three Summer Research Workshops for graduate students and postdocs.


Last Modified: 08/24/2022
Modified by: Dino Lorenzini
